resources.string: Knowing what your triggers are and how to deal with them means you’re more likely to stay well with your asthma.

If you have asthma your airways are already more inflamed than the airways of someone without asthma. This means they’re more sensitive and more likely to react to triggers.\n\n That’s why it’s so important to take your preventer inhaler every day. It keeps down the inflammation in your airways, so you’ll be less likely to react to your asthma triggers.

What’s an asthma trigger?

 An asthma trigger is anything that can set off your asthma symptoms. Common triggers include colds and viruses, pets, cigarette smoke, cold weather and pollen.

 You may have just one or two triggers, or several. What sets off your asthma symptoms may be different to what sets off someone else’s. Everyone with asthma has their own set of asthma triggers.

 It’s helpful to know what your triggers are so you can avoid them if possible.

Why is a reaction to a trigger sometimes worse than at other times?

 Sometimes you may be more likely to react badly to your usual asthma triggers than at other times. This may be because asthma symptoms are caused by more than one asthma trigger at the same time. For example, if you have a cold and you also come into contact with a cat it can cause a stronger reaction.

 “The sensitivity in your airways can vary day to day, month to month and year to year,” says Asthma UK nurse, Kathy. “But to keep things steady, and stay on top of the inflammation, take your preventer inhaler every day as prescribed. That way your triggers are less likely to cause symptoms.”

How to deal with asthma triggers

 Some asthma triggers are avoidable, such as cigarette smoke, pets and alcohol. But it’s impossible to completely avoid others – things like pollen, pollution, and cold weather.

 The good news is there are proven steps you can take to cut your risk of asthma triggers causing asthma symptoms or an asthma attack:

 1. TAKE YOUR PREVENTER MEDICINE EVERY DAY

 The best way to help your body cope well with any asthma triggers is to take your preventer inhaler every day as prescribed.

 Your preventer medicine works away in the background to help inflammation and sensitivity in your airways.

 Taking it every day, and in the right way, means there’s less chance of a reaction if you come into contact with any triggers.

 2. USE A WRITTEN ASTHMA ACTION PLAN

 Use your written asthma action plan to note down your triggers so you can spot when your asthma needs extra help.

 Using an action plan cuts your risk of ending up in hospital due to your asthma. It contains all the information you need to look after your asthma well and reduce your likelihood of getting symptoms.

 If you haven’t got one, download an asthma action plan now and fill it in with your GP or asthma nurse.

 3. GO FOR AN ASTHMA REVIEW AT LEAST ONCE A YEAR

 An asthma review gives you and your GP or asthma nurse a chance to make sure your written asthma action plan is up to date.

 You can check you’re taking the right medicines at the right doses so you’re getting the best protection against your triggers and cutting your risk of an asthma attack.

 You can also check you’re using your inhaler in the best way - it might be that something as simple as a change of inhaler technique could help you manage your asthma better.

Follow this emergency advice if you\'re having an asthma attack.

Step 1 - Sit the person upright - try to keep them calm and reassuring.

 Step 2 - Take one puff of your reliever inhaler (usually blue) every 30-60 up to 10 puffs.

 Step 3 - If you feel worse at any point OR you don't fell better after 10 puffs call 999 for an ambulance.

 Step 4 - Repeat step 2 after 15 minutes while you're waiting for an ambulance.

Call emergency assistance immediately (Dial 999) if …

 - If the person is not breathing

 - If the person's Asthma suddenly becomes worse, or is not improving

 - If the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available

 - if you are not sure if it's asthma

 - if the person is known to Anaphylaxis - Follow Anaphylaxis Action Plan, then give Asthma First Aid (Blue/Grey reliever medication is unlikely to harm, even if the person does not have asthma)

If you have asthma, your airways (breathing tubes) are usually inflamed all the time, not just when you have symptoms. Mucus can block the inside of your airways as well. Sometimes your airways tighten up as well… so there is less space to breathe through, and that\'s what leads to asthma symptoms!

Common symptoms:
 - Wheezing
 - Cough
 - Chest tightness
 - Phlegm/Mucus
 - Shortness of breath
 - Chest pains
Its important to track your symptoms! Keep an eye out, as its a good indication of how well your asthma is controlled.

Managing symptoms\n Know what you specific symptoms and triggers are. If symptoms are not getting better, see your doctor to help you find a better way to control them! And make sure you have a current asthma action plan! it will help you know what you are doing well, and what you need to get help with.

Medication is needed to manage your asthma. Most medications for asthma are inhaled through your mouth using a puffer (inhaler). There are different kinds of medication in the puffers and different kinds of puffer devices. The main two kinds of medication are called relievers and preventers, and they work in different ways.

Reliever Inhalers\n Relievers act quickly, in as little as 4 minutes, to help relive you symptoms. Examples are Ventolin,Asmol and Bricanyl. Everyone with asthma needs to have a reliever puffer for when they have symptoms, or if a doctor has told them to use it before exercise.

Preventer Inhaler Preventers are taken everyday to help your asthma symptoms and flare-ups. They do this by reducing inflammation in your airways. Examples are Pulmicort and Flixoride. If you are using your preventer, your doctor will prescribe the lowest strength of medication that works to manage your asthma. Talk to your doctor about the choices that are available for you asthma treatment.
